TopicTitle: How to get VTOL to take off perfectly straight?

Articles.Content:
So I'm building a heavy VTOL craft (Currently at 114 116 113 tons), and the issue I have is getting the aircraft to be able to take off perfectly vertical. No matter how gently I adjust the position of the VTOL engines, it always tilts either forwards or backwards when taking off vertically, even with SAS on. So my question is, how do I get a plane to take off perfectly vertically? 

 

(If you want more details or pictures of the aircraft, just ask!)

Here's the link to the aircraft with some details: https://kerbalx.com/drtricky/ABH-41-Titan

Edited September 25, 2016 by drtricky

Balancing the thrust may prove difficult as fuel is used.  I would go with more reaction wheel torque to help keep orientation.  I have also heard people angling the vertical engines away from com to improve stability.

Does it continue to tilt, to say 45 degrees or some big number like that, or does it 'even out' if you let it do its own thing with SAS enabled?

Edit: Or maybe bite the bullet and install RCS too. A bit expensive and inefficient but it should augment the SAS power.

Edited September 25, 2016 by Rodhern
suggested adding RCS thrusters

First thing is to adjust in your VAB thrust vs CoG.

If any, set the thrust of your horizontals engines, to 0. you will only see the vertical engines thrust.

Adjust precisely vectors. This is quite difficult with perspective and the tuning shall be sharp to avoid tilting.

Two or more engines is better for stability, and panther are really good with its thrust vectoring.

Do not forget reaction wheels, it helps a lot at low speed.

You can add, a probe or a docking port to point top, if you use mechjeb, you can stabilize your ship pointing top. (It's a little bit tricky to switch back)

 

Take off is a thing, but landing with a random CoG is another thing!

This is kind of good, because it probably means that the SAS is simply being overpowered by torque (isn't that what it is called). So either the overpowering bit needs to be less overpowering, or the SAS must be given more power somehow.

I am sorry that RCS didn't help (it made sense in my head at the time).

RCS at sea level is not very powerful, and shall be placed as far as possible of COG.

Reaction wheel shall be placed as close as possible of CoG.

Aside from the obvious (allign vertical thrust through CoM), I find the biggest issue with VTOLS to be drag-induced pitch rotation in vertical flight... You have to  keep your vertical speed down to avoid pitch up on takeoff / pitch down on landing. Other than that, more reaction wheels or mods - RCS Build Aid for design, Throttle Controlled Avionics and/or jet RCS (some in QuizTech Aero) for flight.

8 minutes ago, drtricky said:

The tilting occurs before the plane even reaches significant vertical speeds.

In that case, it pretty much has to be CoT / CoM alignment and/or lack of control authority, right? Tried RCS Build Aid? It's pretty much a required mod for VTOL design, IMO.

Another thing to note is that gimbals on vertical lift engines can often be counterproductive, depending on where they are placed vertically WRT CoM. Disabling them may actually help stability.

Do you have more than one fuel tank on the plane, with different position regarding forward and aft. In that case make sure they are not filled. At the runway make the plane just barely lift off, notice if it tilts forwards or backwards, cut (or reduce) the power and let it settle back down. Transfer some fuel forward or aft. Try again. Repeat to diagnose the problem. If you are really precise, you may notice either the front or the rear lifting off first.

If the problem is consistent there probably should be a certain balance tip-over point. What we hope will not happen, is that you discover the instability to be more or less random.

btw. Maybe it is time for a picture of the plane. In other threads I have observed some players have a very keen sight for plane details. Edit: you already did

Missed the link in the OP

If you're not doing it already, angle your VTOL engines outward

The above image is greatly exaggerated. 5-10° should be enough.

When the craft leans forward, the front VTOL engines start pointing more vertical, while the rear ones are less vertical. This means the front VTOL creates more downward force. It becomes a form of self-correcting balance.

Likewise if it leans in any other direction.

It does require at least 3 VTOL engines, to work in all 4 directions, but easier to do with 4 or more.
